column4: how can i edit files on my installed ubuntu from a live cd? normally i used
gksu gedit /etc/default/grub for instance. but what path should i use now to edit the files?
i installed ubuntu on an empty pc
there is a disk utility under system - administration which will show you the path to each hard drive
If your pc is empty, then there are no files on it, which renders your question moot?

no thats not what i mean, i installed ubuntu on an empty pc. but now that wont boot anymore because of this http://news.softpedia.com/news/How-to-Fix-the-Big-and-Ugly-Plymouth-Logo-in-Ubuntu-10-04-140810.shtml. now i am trying to fix it from a live cd
and in the disk utility it says: /dev/sda1
if you double-click the disk on the desktop, it will automount it
following that, you will have it under /media/..., just as you have already found it
now you can browse through it this way: cd /media/....
stromcr0w: how should this command then be? gksu gedit /etc/default/grub
yeah it seems to work now, thanks both :)
